oai_dc:dc.dc:title: UNDERSTANDING SURF-ZONE HYDRO-MORPHODYNAMIC PROCESSES IN A TYPICAL POCKET BEACH ALONG THE WEST COAST OF INDIA
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Jeyaraj, Satheeshkumar
Ramakrishnan, Balaji
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Coastal processes are natural processes that operate along coastal zones, resulting in morphological changes in erosion and deposition. The western coast of India is affected by extreme monsoonal wave activity, which can lead to the loss of beaches and the vulnerability of the dunes. As a result, understanding actual near-shore physics and long-shore sediment transport becomes a prerequisite for the development of an effective coastal zone management strategy. The aim of this study is to quantify and investigate longshore sediment flux as a result of wave action based on sediment trap experiments (Kraus 1987). The Kraus (1987) method, along with wave hydrodynamics and current measurements, is performed using acoustic instruments across the surf zone.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Coastal Engineering Proceedings; No. 36v (2020): Proceedings of virtual Conference on Coastal Engineering, 2020; sediment.22
